review.title: A short proof that $O_2$ is an MCFL
review.abstract: We present a new proof that $O_2$ is a multiple context-free language. It contrasts with a recent proof by Salvati (2015) in its avoidance of concepts that seem specific to two-dimensional geometry, such as the complex exponential function. Our simple proof creates realistic prospects of widening the results to higher dimensions. This finding is of central importance to the relation between extreme free word order and classes of grammars used to describe the syntax of natural language.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The alphabet of the MIX language has three symbols, a, b, and c. A string is in the language if and only if the number a, the number b, and the number c are equal. Another way of defining the MIX language is as a permutation closure of the regular language (abc) к, as noted by Bach (1981); see also Pullum (1983).If a, b, and c represent, say, a transitive verb and its subject and its object, then a string in MIX represents a sentence with any number of triples of these components, in a hypothetical language with an extreme free order of words. Admittedly, this is quite different from any actual natural language. Joshi (1985) argued that grammatical formalisms describing natural languages should not be able to generalize the MIX generalization. He also suspected that MIX goes beyond the generative capacity of a particular formality, namely the adjacent grammatics.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and outlook
sections.text: It has at least superficial elements in common with the evidence of Salvati (2015). Both proofs use essentially the same MCFG, both are geometric in nature and both involve a continuous view of the paths alongside a discrete view. The main difference lies in the approach to the myriad ways in which the paths can circumnavigate each other and themselves. In the case of Salvati (2015), the key concept is the complex exponential function that seems to limit the evidential technique to two-dimensional geometry. In our case, the key concepts are excursions and shortcuts of the same. At this point no evidence is within reach that generalizes the result to O3. This requires at least an appropriate definition of "deflection" in three dimensions that are probably more involved than in the two-dimensional case.

A string is in the language if and only if the number of a’s equals the number of a’s, and the number of b’s equals the number of b’s. MIX and O2 are rationally equivalent, which means that if one is generated by a multiple context-free grammar, then so is the other.
